title: Sansa and Bran
body:
I thought I’d take the time to discuss my favourite Stark sibling relationship. While the two of them weren’t as close as Arya and Jon or Jon and Robb, they have a positive relationship despite having different interests. Out of all the Stark children, Sansa and Bran are noted to have enjoyed songs though Bran did not like the romantic ones Sansa enjoyed. 

Lord Wyman’s musicians played bravely and well, but harp and fiddle and horn were soon drowned beneath a tide of talk and laughter, the clash of cup and plate, and the snarling of hounds fighting for table scraps. The singer sang good songs, “Iron Lances” and “The Burning of the Ships” and “The Bear and the Maiden Fair,” but only Hodor seemed to be listening. He stood beside the piper, hopping from one foot to the other.

In fact songs and stories play an important role in Bran’s story especially when he meets the Children. Bran wanted to become a knight just as much as Sansa wanted to attend tourneys.

Bran was going to be a knight himself someday, one of the Kingsguard. Old Nan said they were the finest swords in all the realm. There were only seven of them, and they wore white armor and had no wives or children, but lived only to serve the king. Bran knew all the stories. Their names were like music to him. Serwyn of the Mirror Shield. Ser Ryam Redwyne. Prince Aemon the Dragonknight. The twins Ser Erryk and Ser Arryk, who had died on one another’s swords hundreds of years ago, when brother fought sister in the war the singers called the Dance of the Dragons. The White Bull, Gerold Hightower. Ser Arthur Dayne, the Sword of the Morning. Barristan the Bold. 

She pulled a chair close to the hearth, took down one of her favorite books, and lost herself in the stories of Florian and Jonquil, of Lady Shella and the Rainbow Knight, of valiant Prince Aemon and his doomed love for his brother’s queen. 

“Prince Aemon the Dragonknight cried the day Princess Naerys wed his brother Aegon,” Sansa Stark said, “and the twins Ser Arryk and Ser Erryk died with tears on their cheeks after each had given the other a mortal wound." 

Like Sansa, Bran was excited to go South.

For days, Bran could scarcely wait to be off. He was going to ride the kingsroad on a horse of his own, not a pony but a real horse. His father would be the Hand of the King, and they were going to live in the red castle at King’s Landing, the castle the Dragonlords had built. Old Nan said there were ghosts there, and dungeons where terrible things had been done, and dragon heads on the walls. It gave Bran a shiver just to think of it, but he was not afraid. How could he be afraid? His father would be with him, and the king with all his knights and sworn swords.

An opinion that Sansa no doubt shared. Unfortunately Bran was almost killed and he had to remain in the North. We know Bran’s fall devastated Sansa

She ought to be crying too, she thought, but the tears would not come. Perhaps she had used up all her tears for Lady and Bran.

and we know Lady’s death hurt Bran. 

Bran felt all cold inside. "She lost her wolf,” he said, weakly, remembering the day when four of his father’s guardsmen had returned from the south with Lady’s bones. Summer and Grey Wind and Shaggydog had begun to howl before they crossed the drawbridge, in voices drawn and desolate. Beneath the shadow of the First Keep was an ancient lichyard, its headstones spotted with pale lichen, where the old Kings of Winter had laid their faithful servants. It was there they buried Lady, while her brothers stalked between the graves like restless shadows. She had gone south, and only her bones had returned.

It was the only time that anyone shows any pain on Sansa’s behalf after Lady dies (with the exception of Ned’s anger whenever he remembered killing Lady). That’s what I love most about the relationship, they can’t see each other but they feel for the other as much as possible. I think this is the most uncomplicated relationship that Sansa has. She likes being a lady and that involves a lot of time in doors but besides the remark about kissing songs, Bran has no problem with what Sansa enjoys. He even remembered the feast they held in Robert’s in honor in which he noted how Sansa was listening intently to the singers without making a disparaging remark, something other characters find difficult. Sansa and Bran’s arcs contain a lot of trauma, something uncomplicated as their love for one another is sweet and will probably go a long way in healing them when they meet again.

The other thing that I love most about the two of them is how their arcs mirror each other. One could argue that all the remaining Stark siblings have similar journeys but I think Sansa and Bran’s resemble each other closely. In book one, Ned arranges Sansa’s betrothal so he’d have a cover to investigate the Lannisters and wants to use Bran to bridge the gap between Robb and Joffrey. However, their dreams unravel pretty quickly. Bran is disabled and Sansa’s court life meets one set back after another. As a disabled person, I am hesitant to compare the two situations but seeing as the Trident incident laid the foundation for a future of abuse, I’m going to continue. Both Bran and Sansa try to deal with their circumstances, the only difference is that Sansa’s coping mechanism means that she pretends everything is fine. 

In A Clash of Kings, both of them find themselves thrust in new situations. While Bran is the second son, he was only 8 when he acted as Lord of Winterfell and he was 7 when Ned was still teaching him, Robb is now King and he only has Luwin and Rodrick as advisors. 

“You are the lord in Winterfell now,” Robb told him. He was mounted on a shaggy grey stallion, his shield hung from the horse’s side; wood banded with iron, white and grey, and on it the snarling face of a direwolf. His brother wore grey chainmail over bleached leathers, sword and dagger at his waist, a fur-trimmed cloak across his shoulders. “You must take my place, as I took Father’s, until we come home.”

“I know,” Bran replied miserably. He had never felt so little or alone or scared. He did not know how to be a lord. 

Sansa is a prisoner of war still betrothed to Joffrey and she has to find a way to survive on her own, something she hasn’t been taught fully. 

The balcony was deserted save for Sansa. She stood with her head bowed, fighting to hold back her tears, while below Joffrey sat on his Iron Throne and dispensed what it pleased him to call justice. Nine cases out of ten seemed to bore him; those he allowed his council to handle, squirming restlessly while Lord Baelish, Grand Maester Pycelle, or Queen Cersei resolved the matter. When he did choose to make a ruling, though, not even his queen mother could sway him. 

“I’ll get you with child as soon as you’re able,” Joffrey said as he escorted her across the practice yard. “If the first one is stupid, I’ll chop off your head and find a smarter wife…

Interestingly, they both of the engage in diplomacy (though it’s called courtesy in Sansa’s chapters). The both of them have to bite their tongue often, in Bran’s case usually when he faces ableism or whenever he needs to make a ruling and in Sansa’s case, whenever her family is insulted or when she’s being abused. While they’re unhappy due to the war, the death of their father, the separation of their family, it should be noted that they’re good at their tasks and they survive the book. By the end of A Clash of Kings, their situations grew more bleak. Stannis lost and the Lannisters gained a powerful ally while Winterfell burned. The last few lines of Bran’s last ACoK apply to him and the Starks as whole.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

Despite everything, they’re still alive, they still have a fighting chance. In ASoS, Bran and Sansa are focused on one goal each: finding the three eyed crow and escaping King’s Landing (while Sansa has been looking for a way out, the situation became dire enough that merely surviving was not enough, she had to become proactive). Their arcs in the book are filled with hope that either fell through (Willas) or they let go (Jon). Eventually they reach their destinations and meet the men who have affected their lives so completely. For Bran it’s Brynden Rivers, one of the most powerful beings in the world who has been searching for a successor in the war against the Others and for Sansa it’s Littlefinger who caused the War of the Five Kings. Both Bran and Sansa have to go into hiding, Bran in the cave beyond the Wall and Sansa by hiding her identity. It’s important for them to learn from these men despite how morally reprehensible they both are. Neither of them are particularly happy but it’s important for their arc. Many dark elements are either introduced or continued- cannibalism, sexual abuse, human sacrifice, war mongering, etc. Unlike many people in the fandom, I think both Sansa and Bran will react with horror when they learn the full extent of what their mentors are doing and in TWoW, they’ll both reject their mentors and escape them one way or the other.

When Sansa and Bran meet again, it’s bound to be emotional and loving. They have both gone through hell and have been changed by it but deep down they’re still the same compassionate people they always were. As far as the Stark succession crisis, whether the Girl in Grey theory or the Sansa comes North with the Vale Army theory is true, I’m certain Sansa will support Bran’s claim. Regardless of what happens I’m looking forward to them meeting again.

By the end of A Clash of Kings, their situations grew more bleak. Stannis lost and the Lannisters gained a powerful ally while Winterfell burned. The last few lines of Bran’s last ACoK apply to him and the Starks as whole.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

Despite everything, they’re still alive, they still have a fighting chance. In ASoS, Bran and Sansa are focused on one goal each: finding the three eyed crow and escaping King’s Landing (while Sansa has been looking for a way out, the situation became dire enough that merely surviving was not enough, she had to become proactive). Their arcs in the book are filled with hope that either fell through (Willas) or they let go (Jon). Eventually they reach their destinations and meet the men who have affected their lives so completely. For Bran it’s Brynden Rivers, one of the most powerful beings in the world who has been searching for a successor in the war against the Others and for Sansa it’s Littlefinger who caused the War of the Five Kings. Both Bran and Sansa have to go into hiding, Bran in the cave beyond the Wall and Sansa by hiding her identity. It’s important for them to learn from these men despite how morally reprehensible they both are. Neither of them are particularly happy but it’s important for their arc. Many dark elements are either introduced or continued- cannibalism, sexual abuse, human sacrifice, war mongering, etc. Unlike many people in the fandom, I think both Sansa and Bran will react with horror when they learn the full extent of what their mentors are doing and in TWoW, they’ll both reject their mentors and escape them one way or the other.

When Sansa and Bran meet again, it’s bound to be emotional and loving. They have both gone through hell and have been changed by it but deep down they’re still the same compassionate people they always were. As far as the Stark succession crisis, whether the Girl in Grey theory or the Sansa comes North with the Vale Army theory is true, I’m certain Sansa will support Bran’s claim. Regardless of what happens I’m looking forward to them meeting again.
trail.content:
I thought I’d take the time to discuss my favourite Stark sibling relationship. While the two of them weren’t as close as Arya and Jon or Jon and Robb, they have a positive relationship despite having different interests. Out of all the Stark children, Sansa and Bran are noted to have enjoyed songs though Bran did not like the romantic ones Sansa enjoyed. 

Lord Wyman’s musicians played bravely and well, but harp and fiddle and horn were soon drowned beneath a tide of talk and laughter, the clash of cup and plate, and the snarling of hounds fighting for table scraps. The singer sang good songs, “Iron Lances” and “The Burning of the Ships” and “The Bear and the Maiden Fair,” but only Hodor seemed to be listening. He stood beside the piper, hopping from one foot to the other.

In fact songs and stories play an important role in Bran’s story especially when he meets the Children. Bran wanted to become a knight just as much as Sansa wanted to attend tourneys.

Bran was going to be a knight himself someday, one of the Kingsguard. Old Nan said they were the finest swords in all the realm. There were only seven of them, and they wore white armor and had no wives or children, but lived only to serve the king. Bran knew all the stories. Their names were like music to him. Serwyn of the Mirror Shield. Ser Ryam Redwyne. Prince Aemon the Dragonknight. The twins Ser Erryk and Ser Arryk, who had died on one another’s swords hundreds of years ago, when brother fought sister in the war the singers called the Dance of the Dragons. The White Bull, Gerold Hightower. Ser Arthur Dayne, the Sword of the Morning. Barristan the Bold. 

She pulled a chair close to the hearth, took down one of her favorite books, and lost herself in the stories of Florian and Jonquil, of Lady Shella and the Rainbow Knight, of valiant Prince Aemon and his doomed love for his brother’s queen. 

“Prince Aemon the Dragonknight cried the day Princess Naerys wed his brother Aegon,” Sansa Stark said, “and the twins Ser Arryk and Ser Erryk died with tears on their cheeks after each had given the other a mortal wound." 

Like Sansa, Bran was excited to go South.

For days, Bran could scarcely wait to be off. He was going to ride the kingsroad on a horse of his own, not a pony but a real horse. His father would be the Hand of the King, and they were going to live in the red castle at King’s Landing, the castle the Dragonlords had built. Old Nan said there were ghosts there, and dungeons where terrible things had been done, and dragon heads on the walls. It gave Bran a shiver just to think of it, but he was not afraid. How could he be afraid? His father would be with him, and the king with all his knights and sworn swords.

An opinion that Sansa no doubt shared. Unfortunately Bran was almost killed and he had to remain in the North. We know Bran’s fall devastated Sansa

She ought to be crying too, she thought, but the tears would not come. Perhaps she had used up all her tears for Lady and Bran.

and we know Lady’s death hurt Bran. 

Bran felt all cold inside. "She lost her wolf,” he said, weakly, remembering the day when four of his father’s guardsmen had returned from the south with Lady’s bones. Summer and Grey Wind and Shaggydog had begun to howl before they crossed the drawbridge, in voices drawn and desolate. Beneath the shadow of the First Keep was an ancient lichyard, its headstones spotted with pale lichen, where the old Kings of Winter had laid their faithful servants. It was there they buried Lady, while her brothers stalked between the graves like restless shadows. She had gone south, and only her bones had returned.

It was the only time that anyone shows any pain on Sansa’s behalf after Lady dies (with the exception of Ned’s anger whenever he remembered killing Lady). That’s what I love most about the relationship, they can’t see each other but they feel for the other as much as possible. I think this is the most uncomplicated relationship that Sansa has. She likes being a lady and that involves a lot of time in doors but besides the remark about kissing songs, Bran has no problem with what Sansa enjoys. He even remembered the feast they held in Robert’s in honor in which he noted how Sansa was listening intently to the singers without making a disparaging remark, something other characters find difficult. Sansa and Bran’s arcs contain a lot of trauma, something uncomplicated as their love for one another is sweet and will probably go a long way in healing them when they meet again.

The other thing that I love most about the two of them is how their arcs mirror each other. One could argue that all the remaining Stark siblings have similar journeys but I think Sansa and Bran’s resemble each other closely. In book one, Ned arranges Sansa’s betrothal so he’d have a cover to investigate the Lannisters and wants to use Bran to bridge the gap between Robb and Joffrey. However, their dreams unravel pretty quickly. Bran is disabled and Sansa’s court life meets one set back after another. As a disabled person, I am hesitant to compare the two situations but seeing as the Trident incident laid the foundation for a future of abuse, I’m going to continue. Both Bran and Sansa try to deal with their circumstances, the only difference is that Sansa’s coping mechanism means that she pretends everything is fine. 

In A Clash of Kings, both of them find themselves thrust in new situations. While Bran is the second son, he was only 8 when he acted as Lord of Winterfell and he was 7 when Ned was still teaching him, Robb is now King and he only has Luwin and Rodrick as advisors. 

“You are the lord in Winterfell now,” Robb told him. He was mounted on a shaggy grey stallion, his shield hung from the horse’s side; wood banded with iron, white and grey, and on it the snarling face of a direwolf. His brother wore grey chainmail over bleached leathers, sword and dagger at his waist, a fur-trimmed cloak across his shoulders. “You must take my place, as I took Father’s, until we come home.”

“I know,” Bran replied miserably. He had never felt so little or alone or scared. He did not know how to be a lord. 

Sansa is a prisoner of war still betrothed to Joffrey and she has to find a way to survive on her own, something she hasn’t been taught fully. 

The balcony was deserted save for Sansa. She stood with her head bowed, fighting to hold back her tears, while below Joffrey sat on his Iron Throne and dispensed what it pleased him to call justice. Nine cases out of ten seemed to bore him; those he allowed his council to handle, squirming restlessly while Lord Baelish, Grand Maester Pycelle, or Queen Cersei resolved the matter. When he did choose to make a ruling, though, not even his queen mother could sway him. 

“I’ll get you with child as soon as you’re able,” Joffrey said as he escorted her across the practice yard. “If the first one is stupid, I’ll chop off your head and find a smarter wife…

Interestingly, they both of the engage in diplomacy (though it’s called courtesy in Sansa’s chapters). The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

Despite everything, they’re still alive, they still have a fighting chance. In ASoS, Bran and Sansa are focused on one goal each: finding the three eyed crow and escaping King’s Landing (while Sansa has been looking for a way out, the situation became dire enough that merely surviving was not enough, she had to become proactive). Their arcs in the book are filled with hope that either fell through (Willas) or they let go (Jon). Eventually they reach their destinations and meet the men who have affected their lives so completely. For Bran it’s Brynden Rivers, one of the most powerful beings in the world who has been searching for a successor in the war against the Others and for Sansa it’s Littlefinger who caused the War of the Five Kings. Both Bran and Sansa have to go into hiding, Bran in the cave beyond the Wall and Sansa by hiding her identity. It’s important for them to learn from these men despite how morally reprehensible they both are. Neither of them are particularly happy but it’s important for their arc. Many dark elements are either introduced or continued- cannibalism, sexual abuse, human sacrifice, war mongering, etc. Unlike many people in the fandom, I think both Sansa and Bran will react with horror when they learn the full extent of what their mentors are doing and in TWoW, they’ll both reject their mentors and escape them one way or the other.

When Sansa and Bran meet again, it’s bound to be emotional and loving. They have both gone through hell and have been changed by it but deep down they’re still the same compassionate people they always were. As far as the Stark succession crisis, whether the Girl in Grey theory or the Sansa comes North with the Vale Army theory is true, I’m certain Sansa will support Bran’s claim. Regardless of what happens I’m looking forward to them meeting again.

summary: Listening to grrm it’s clear dragons are not the solution. He compares the white walkers and winter is coming to climate change...
question: Listening to grrm it’s clear dragons are not the solution. He compares the white walkers and winter is coming to climate change and he compares dragons to nuclear weapons. You don’t throw nukes at climate change to make it better. That only makes it worse (like giving the NK a dragon). The clear answer to that problem is the person with nature magic (Bran) the only question left will be to see how he does it.
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

I’m not sure GRRM ever said that the white walkers and winter is coming are connected to climate change. That seems to be a parallel fans and, in particular, the media have drawn. What he’s said is that he was inspired by  real life in building the Lannister vs. Stark conflict while simultaneously adding the distant threat of the White Walkers and D*ny and her dragons by our society’s inability to take climate change seriously and focus on preparing for that threat. So instead of the WW being a representation of climate change per se, GRRM’s commentary is based on the characters’ dismissal of their existence in the same way factions in our own society try to dismiss climate change as an actual, life-threatening problem. 

But yes, I agree, the dragons and the WWs are both representatives of extremes and are equally destructive just that in opposite ways (WW with ice; Dragons with fire). In that sense, they represent GRRM’s interpretation of Frost’s poem: 

Some say the world will end in fire,
Some say in ice.
From what I’ve tasted of desire
I hold with those who favor fire.
But if it had to perish twice,
I think I know enough of hate
To say that for destruction ice
Is also great
And would suffice.

GRRM has admitted that he was inspired by this poem in naming his series: A song of ice and fire and I’m pretty sure that the portrayal of the WWs and Dragons in his books also hankers back to this poem. How anyone can look at that poem and conclude that Fire is not only good but is the salvation to the Ice apocalypse is beyond me but there you have it. 

Bran, on the other hand, is essentially the balance between these two extremes. He is neither Fire nor Ice. His power is the power of the Earth and in that sense his power nurtures and heals the destructive forces of ice and fire. So, thematically, it makes sense that he would be the one that is the key to defeating the WWs and perhaps also have a hand to play in destroying the dragons. 

A lot of people dismiss Bran because they simply haven’t figured out how he’s going to stop the NK. And instead of simply accepting the fact that we don’t have enough information to make more than an educated guess, they decide that there must be nothing more to Bran than being the Wikipedia of Winterfell. I sincerely doubt that is the case. 

Thanks for the ask!

A lot of people dismiss Bran because they simply haven’t figured out how he’s going to stop the NK. And instead of simply accepting the fact that we don’t have enough information to make more than an educated guess, they decide that there must be nothing more to Bran than being the Wikipedia of Winterfell. I sincerely doubt that is the case. 

Thanks for the ask!
trail.content:
Hey, nonnie!

I’m not sure GRRM ever said that the white walkers and winter is coming are connected to climate change. That seems to be a parallel fans and, in particular, the media have drawn. What he’s said is that he was inspired by  real life in building the Lannister vs. Stark conflict while simultaneously adding the distant threat of the White Walkers and D*ny and her dragons by our society’s inability to take climate change seriously and focus on preparing for that threat. So instead of the WW being a representation of climate change per se, GRRM’s commentary is based on the characters’ dismissal of their existence in the same way factions in our own society try to dismiss climate change as an actual, life-threatening problem. 

But yes, I agree, the dragons and the WWs are both representatives of extremes and are equally destructive just that in opposite ways (WW with ice; Dragons with fire). In that sense, they represent GRRM’s interpretation of Frost’s poem: 

Some say the world will end in fire,
Some say in ice.
From what I’ve tasted of desire
I hold with those who favor fire.
But if it had to perish twice,
I think I know enough of hate
To say that for destruction ice
Is also great
And would suffice.

GRRM has admitted that he was inspired by this poem in naming his series: A song of ice and fire and I’m pretty sure that the portrayal of the WWs and Dragons in his books also hankers back to this poem. How anyone can look at that poem and conclude that Fire is not only good but is the salvation to the Ice apocalypse is beyond me but there you have it. 

Bran, on the other hand, is essentially the balance between these two extremes. He is neither Fire nor Ice. His power is the power of the Earth and in that sense his power nurtures and heals the destructive forces of ice and fire. So, thematically, it makes sense that he would be the one that is the key to defeating the WWs and perhaps also have a hand to play in destroying the dragons. 

A lot of people dismiss Bran because they simply haven’t figured out how he’s going to stop the NK. And instead of simply accepting the fact that we don’t have enough information to make more than an educated guess, they decide that there must be nothing more to Bran than being the Wikipedia of Winterfell. I sincerely doubt that is the case. 

Thanks for the ask!

summary: Hey, Thanks for answering my question and showing me that d@ny & storm meta. I intend to portray jon as a heroic but also...
question: Hey, Thanks for answering my question and showing me that d@ny & storm meta. I intend to portray jon as a heroic but also destructive savior where if he is not calm he will cause more destruction than the enemy, just like a dragon does, so he represents both wind(unstoppable) and storm(devastating). I am not very well versed with lotr so could you tell me if bloodraven is more like saruman or an evil gandalf or an entirely different figure? I treat him as a friend of humanity but not the heroes.
answer:
Hi there!

I do think that any wielder of magic in ASOIAF has a destructive force as well. So, Jon destroying some things while saving the world from Euron makes sense to me.

Bloodraven…. Well, I do think he is more of a Saruman figure, although in a way he is not. Tolkien made no secret about Saruman’s fall. We learn about Saruman and his own evil agenda when Gandalf tells everyone at Elrond’s council how they were betrayed. So there is no element of surprise there, not really.

With Bloodraven I would say that the motives are similar to Saruman. If my hunch is right he was recruited by the Children of the Forest and managed to dupe them. He then made Euron his apprentice, but he went rogue and then Bloodraven reached out to Bran. But his motives are not selfless and my suspicion is that he wants to use the magic that was let lose with the re-emerging of the WW to get immortality. He might be after a young, male Targ he can inhabit, and my suspicion is, that he is after Jon. He might also be the person who is behind Aegon’s V obsession with dragons and the tragedy of Summerhall. So his motives are selfish and in this regard he is like Saruman, only it is not that obvious to the reader.

An evil Gandalf would not necessarily be selfish, but more like a smaller “dark lord”, in a way more frightening and more surreal than Saruman. So I think I would stick to Saruman as a parallel, even though Bloodraven’s treason is not as easily seen as Saruman’s.

Thanks for the ask!

summary: I enjoyed your Prophecies ask.  Any thought to Jaime being valonqar via Bran warging into him?  Both would meet the younger...
question: I enjoyed your Prophecies ask.  Any thought to Jaime being valonqar via Bran warging into him?  Both would meet the younger brother aspect of her or YMBQ's. I see Cersei's death as very personal.  Bran getting retribution for Broken Tower on having Jaime kill Cersei seems very fitting both for Jaime (making him live with doing this because I'm not sure if he could do it on his own) and obv Cersei. Two birds.  He's one of the only main characters who has not gotten to slay his own demons.
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

Thank you. :)

I know that Bran being the valonqar through warging is a theory that has recently began circulating. The first meta I read on the subject is from @lostlittlesatellites and she makes some interesting points. So I would definitely not dismiss it outright. 

However, I don’t particularly ascribe to this theory and less so to Bran warging Jaime specifically. In a narrative sense, I think it would be a cop out to simultaneously have Jaime kill Cersei but not really because it’s actually Bran doing it. I think with the idea of Jaime as the valonqar, the only way to make it effective, personal and for it to have the tragic narrative impact that I believe such a plot twist would have is to fully commit to it and have Jaime kill her for his own reasons, reasons that should not, by the way, be connected to Brienne in any way. 

I don’t know if you are familiar with Pascal Bruckner’s “Lunes de fiel”. In essence that book is about a couple involved in the most extreme version of a toxic relationship you can imagine and the ending of it finds both of them crippled and disfigured at each other’s hands. In a way that’s how I see the Jaime/Cersei relationship. There is love there but they also hurt and use each other in abhorrent ways so the Jaime as the valonqar theory feels like the satisfying end to their relationship. It’s personal, it’s painful, it’s the toxic end to a relationship that has harmed and twisted both of them. In that sense, I believe there’s also a chance that Jaime will die alongside her. 

As for this: 

Bran getting retribution for Broken Tower on having Jaime kill Cersei seems very fitting both for Jaime (making him live with doing this because I’m not sure if he could do it on his own) and obv Cersei. Two birds. He’s one of the only main characters who has not gotten to slay his own demons.

I’m not really all that comfortable with the idea of revenge and retribution being connected to slaying your demons. And we’ve seen in this story that it actually doesn’t work out that way.

 Does Arya killing the Freys help her heal? She follows that up with threatening to cut her sister’s face off. 

Does killing Ramsay help Sansa move beyond the abuse that was inflicted on her? She’s still cutting herself off, still reluctant to let people in and warping her body in a clothing cage. 

Does executing the Night’s watch brothers help Jon move past his assassination? He’s still haunted by it, as he’s haunted by the execution of Ollie, in particular. 

Killing people does not slay demons or help one heal. Working on yourself, taking time to process your trauma and being around people who love you and care for you, ends up slaying your demons. So in a way the thing that would help Bran the most is, just like all the other Starks, his pack. 

Thanks for the ask!

summary: I also love the King Bran endgame but it also means Sansa has to leave Winterfell. But if the show really leads to book end I'm...
question: I also love the King Bran endgame but it also means Sansa has to leave Winterfell. But if the show really leads to book end I'm convinced there will be no Winterfell in the end and perhaps North too. (We've alredy seen filming photos, Winterfell will be destroyed). So maybe Stark children will be forced to find another home
answer:
Not necessarily. I think GRRM wrote Sansa as having the biggest connection to the South for a reason and I also think she’ll be in a position of power at the end of the books. Also Bran being king doesn’t mean Sansa has to leave, she’s a Stark, she can stay if she wants to and become one of his advisors but I think she’ll be doing something else.

As for that spoiler, unlike book Winterfell, show Winterfell isn’t strong enough to survive the Night King but I’m certain they’ll rebuild Winterfell again. It’s been the Stark home for thousands of years. Also they’re not building a new set just for a few scenes.
